channel.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
channel.description:
Robert Brandl of [ToolTester Network](https://www.tooltester.net/) built his company by developing excellent SEO skills. In this episode he turns his skills to Saber Feedback, and gives me awesome advice on how to solve my SEO problems.
We also talk about his recent acquisition of https://howtogetonline.com/
<iframe height="200px" width="100%" frameborder="no" scrolling="no" seamless src="https://player.simplecast.com/ef3cfb8b-fec3-4cde-b3ef-a6b376001133?dark=false"></iframe>
[You can also listen to this episode here](https://bootstrapped.fm/150-how-to-solve-my-seo-problems-with-robert-brandl-of-tooltester-network/).
Other links:
* Robert on Twitter: [@robertbrandl](https://twitter.com/RobertBrandl) * [Saber Feedback's guide to feedback buttons](https://saberfeedback.com/feedback-button/)

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
gravelld:

You spent a bit of time talking about guest posting and getting inbound links. What was your strategy for that in the end, and how successful were you?

I find getting backlinks really hard. It isn’t in my nature to do the hard work required.

However a podcast listener invited me to write a guest blog post after listening to this episode. (It’s here btw: Feedback Button vs. Survey Widget vs. Online Poll) . This was a big help - even getting one backlink seemed to help with this low-competition keyword.

I asked a couple of podcasts if I could be a guest, and got three podcast appearances as a result. That got me links to my site in the show notes, although they didn’t link directly to my “feedback buttons” page.

Read full topic

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
It has been a few months since @tooltester and I recorded this episode. Time to report back on how his tips went for me.

To recap, in the episode, I asked for tips on making my “Guide to feedback buttons” page rank in position 1 for Google search results for “feedback button”.

I then went about applying the tips, one by one.

This screenshot from Google Search Console shows how the “Guide to feedback buttons” page has ranked over time in Google search results for “feedback button”:

Screen Shot 2021-03-11 at 9.09.48 am950×369 11.7 KB

About a week ago the page finally cemented itself in position 1.

What happened a week ago? I finally applied the last outstanding tip I was given: I added a video to the page, in which I more or less read out the info on the page.

Could be coincidence, or it could be that the Google search results reward having a video on this type of page.

Read full topic

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: tooltester
item.description:
Hi, missed your question about other tools. We use:

  • Screaming Frog for site crawls to find (technical) SEO errors
  • AccuRanker and SE Ranking for keyword monitoring (rankings)
  • Hexometer for general website health monitoring (finds broken links!)

Read full topic

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: ivm
item.description:
Yes, for market research and possible SEO strategies, but I think the same CSV-exporting approach will work for content creation too (unless you create something time-sensitive that needs weekly monitoring).

Right now I’m returning to one project after a two-year hiatus and the exports I got from Ahrefs in late 2018 are still viable because the niche is not too busy.

Read full topic

Ah, so you use it to evaluate product ideas? Most people use it for content creation

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: ivm
item.description:
Yep, both are great to explore before starting to work on a new product because it more or less answers what do people have in mind when they search for something related to your idea, how hard would it be to get to the top search results on the first page, and where your future competitors have been getting reviews and backlinks so far.

Read full topic

item.source: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: ivm
item.description:
spek:

Definitely great tool set, but the price tag is heavy.

I was reducing the cost by subscribing for a month, exporting a ton of CSVs, and then disabling the subscription for at least a few months if not half a year. Backlinks and keyword do not change that much inside one year and working in spreadsheets is faster anyway.

Read full topic
item.source: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network

item.title: #150: How to solve my SEO problems, with Robert Brandl of ToolTester Network
item.dc:creator: spek
item.description:
tooltester:

Hey! What you could do is to share one Ahrefs account with other people. Not sure if that’s against their ToS but hey, it is an expensive piece of software. I haven’t seen any other SEO tool as useful and easy to use as Ahrefs.

Hey, yeah, we did this for a while - the ‘regular’ account constantly logged you out when someone else went in. So sharing became a pain really. Definitely great tool set, but the price tag is heavy. What else are you using besides Ahrefs?

Read full topic

yup, that one is included.
